elements.title: Risk-Absorption-First Information Hierarchy
elements.problem: Mahesh asks about financial risk three separate times during a 13-minute call: payment guarantee (02:17, 10:45), deposit handling (09:34), and property damage resolution (12:04). Each time, Bryant answers the question, but the information is delivered reactively -- only after Mahesh probes. Cold Start Theory identifies the hard side as having 'complex workflows' and 'higher expectations' that must be satisfied before they will form an atomic network. When the platform presents information about a listing, a guest, or a proposal, the current architecture forces the host to hunt for the single most important data point: 'Am I financially protected?' If the host must scroll past guest photos, stay dates, and amenity details before finding the guarantee, the information hierarchy is inverted relative to the host's actual decision tree. Mahesh's decision tree is: (1) Is my income guaranteed? (2) Is my property protected? (3) Who is this guest? (4) What are the logistics? Every screen that places logistics or guest details above guarantees misreads the hard side's scan priority.
elements.solution: Structure every commitment-adjacent screen so that risk-absorption information occupies the primary visual position (top of hierarchy, largest type, first in scan order). On the proposal card: lead with 'Payment Guaranteed: $2,600/mo' and 'Property Protected: $1M Coverage Active' as the first two data points, before the guest name or stay dates. On the pricing confirmation: embed the guarantee inline with the rate ('$2,600/month -- guaranteed regardless of occupancy'). On the active lease dashboard: show a persistent 'Protection Status' bar at the top that confirms payment guarantee and property coverage are active, updated in real time. The host's eye should land on protection status before anything else. Guest details and logistics are important but secondary -- they answer 'who and when,' not the gating question of 'am I safe.'

evidence.quote: Even if you are not able to find this ghost roommate setup, I'm still getting paid whatever first month.
evidence.insight: Mahesh's first financial question is not about the rate -- it is about the guarantee. His information priority is protection first, amount second. The IA must mirror this priority.

evidence.quote: How does the deposit get sorted out? Is that something that I would work with you or would that with the...
evidence.insight: The host needs to know the counterparty for disputes before he can evaluate the arrangement. 'Who do I work with if something goes wrong?' is a structural question that must be answered by the information architecture, not by a phone call.

evidence.quote: Users on the hard side have complex workflows, expect status benefits as well as financial outcomes, and will try competitive products to compare.
evidence.insight: The hard side comparison-shops (Mahesh vs. Furnished Finder at 07:29). If Split Lease's IA buries guarantees below guest details, the host's scan pattern will not find the differentiating information before attention shifts to the competitor.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary. Guarantees and protection status must be the first information the host encounters on any decision screen. Rationale: the hard side's gating question is 'am I safe?' not 'who is this person?' -- answering the gating question first unlocks willingness to process secondary information.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Always-visible, non-collapsible. The guarantee headline ('Payment Guaranteed', 'Property Protected: $1M') is shown at the top of every proposal, pricing, and lease screen. Detailed terms (coverage exclusions, claim process, payout timeline) are one tap away in an expandable section. Never hide the headline behind a link, tooltip, or FAQ.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 2 data points in the primary risk-absorption position: (1) payment guarantee status and (2) property protection status. Additional protection details (deposit held, vetting status) are secondary. If more than 2 items compete for primary position, the host's scan fragments and the gating question goes unanswered.

elements.title: Gatekeeper-Ready Information Export Layer
elements.problem: Mahesh's management company requires a guest application (04:25-04:30: 'I probably need that information to share with my management because they do require application'). The platform currently has no mechanism to export guest information in a format the management company expects. Mahesh must become the translator: he receives vetting information from Split Lease, mentally reformats it, and then relays it to his management company in whatever format they accept. This translation labor is a cognitive tax that Cold Start Theory identifies as an enterprise adoption barrier: 'There are enterprise products like Workday that require the company to implement them before there's any value.' The information architecture fails because it treats the host as the sole consumer of guest information. In reality, there are two consumers: the host (who needs to evaluate the guest personally) and the management company (who needs a standard rental application format). The same underlying data must be structured for two different audiences, or the atomic network never forms.
elements.solution: Add a 'Share with Management' information export that restructures the guest's vetted profile into a format recognizable as a standard rental application. This export contains: (1) Applicant name, (2) Employment/income verification, (3) Credit check summary (pass/fail with score range, not raw data), (4) References or prior rental history, (5) Intended occupancy dates and pattern (Mon-Fri, 3 months), (6) Split Lease's guarantee terms as the co-signer/guarantor statement, (7) Contact information for the Split Lease agent handling the booking. The format should be a downloadable PDF or a shareable link that requires no login. The IA principle: the same data (guest vetting results) must be queryable in two views -- a host-facing view (conversational, trust-building) and a gatekeeper-facing view (formal, application-like). The underlying data model is one; the presentation layers are two.

evidence.quote: I probably need that information to share with my management because they do require application.
evidence.insight: Mahesh introduces the management company as a data consumer without hesitation. This is not an edge case -- it is his standard workflow. The IA must serve this second audience or the host cannot proceed.

evidence.quote: Do I have to send most of them to, to find management company I'm here on something that I'll have to, I'll have to figure out?
evidence.insight: Mahesh is uncertain about the information flow between Split Lease and his management company. This uncertainty multiplies friction: he does not know what information to send, in what format, or through what channel.

evidence.quote: There are enterprise products like Workday that require the company to implement them before there's any value. Here, a viral growth strategy is difficult, because it's not enough to dribble in a few users at a time.
evidence.insight: The management company is a micro-enterprise that must be 'sold' with documentation in its expected format. The IA must treat this third-party data need as a first-class information pathway, not an afterthought.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary for gatekeeper-facing view; secondary for host-facing view. The host sees the guest's profile in a trust-building format (conversational, with endorsement). The gatekeeper sees the same data in an application format (formal, with verification checkmarks). Both views are generated from the same data; neither requires the host to manually reformat.
elements.disclosure_pattern: On-demand generation with pre-population. The 'Share with Management' action appears on the proposal screen after the host has reviewed the guest profile. One tap generates the management-company-formatted document. The host can preview before sending. Fields auto-populate from the guest's vetted profile; the host adds only the management company's email or contact.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The management company document must contain no more than 7 data fields on the first page (applicant name, employment, credit summary, rental history, occupancy dates, guarantee terms, agent contact). Additional detail (full vetting report, agreement terms) is attached as a second page. The host should not need to answer the question 'what does my management company need?' -- the platform should already know.

elements.title: Layered Novelty Disclosure for Ghost Roommate Concept
elements.problem: The ghost roommate concept is a novel arrangement that Mahesh has never encountered (08:31: 'I've never dealt with that kind of a situation, obviously it comes with little complications'). Bryant introduces it mid-conversation as 'something called a ghost roommate match' (07:34), immediately after Mahesh has just expressed comparison-anchoring to Furnished Finder (07:29). The information architecture problem: the ghost roommate is simultaneously the platform's strongest differentiator (doubled property yield) and its highest cognitive-load feature (two guests, shared cleaning, overlapping schedules). Cold Start Theory's 'Hitting the Ceiling' chapter identifies context collapse as what happens when network complexity exceeds user capacity. If all ghost roommate information is delivered at once -- economics, logistics, cleaning protocol, schedule overlap, opt-in/opt-out terms -- the host's working memory saturates and the concept collapses into 'complicated.' The IA must disclose ghost roommate information in layers that match the host's readiness to absorb each layer.
elements.solution: Structure ghost roommate information into three disclosure layers, each gated by the host's current phase and decision state. Layer 1 (Evaluation): Introduce the concept as an optional economic upside with one data point: 'Your guaranteed rate is $2,600/mo. With a weekend ghost roommate, potential total income could reach $X/mo.' No operational details yet. The host is deciding whether to join the platform, not whether to manage two guests. Layer 2 (Match Found): When a ghost roommate match is identified, present a 'Ghost Roommate Preview' that adds operational context: proposed weekend guest profile, specific schedule (Friday 6pm to Monday 8am), cleaning handoff protocol, and the incremental income. This is a decision screen with both economic and operational data. Layer 3 (Active Lease): Once opted in, provide an ongoing 'Ghost Roommate Operations' view in the Stays Manager showing the weekly handoff schedule, cleaning status, and escalation contacts. Each layer builds on the previous; no layer front-loads information the host cannot act on yet.

evidence.quote: Another thing which we'll do in Ariel's case, this could work out is as something called a ghost roommate match. So in Ariel's case, she'll be in the space Monday to Friday. And there's potential that we can find someone who'd be interested in a Friday to Monday stay.
evidence.insight: Bryant introduces the concept with the economic frame (potential additional income) before any operational detail. This is the correct Layer 1 disclosure: concept + upside, no complexity yet.

evidence.quote: I've never dealt with that kind of a situation, obviously it comes with little complications.
evidence.insight: Mahesh's word 'complications' signals that his working memory has already begun modeling operational complexity. At this point, dumping cleaning protocols and schedule details would exceed his processing capacity. The IA must pause and let the concept settle before adding operational layers.

evidence.quote: There's fraudsters, overcrowding, and context collapse -- all natural outcomes of a network that grows and matures.
evidence.insight: Two guests in one property is a miniature context collapse: the host's mental model of 'my tenant' must bifurcate. Layered disclosure prevents this collapse from happening all at once by letting the host build the two-tenant model incrementally.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Tertiary during evaluation (optional upside, not core proposition). Primary during active lease ghost roommate management (the host needs operations data front-and-center once opted in). The hierarchy shifts from background to foreground as the host's context changes.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Three-layer progressive disclosure gated by phase: Layer 1 (evaluation) = concept + single economic data point. Layer 2 (match found) = full preview with economics and operations side-by-side. Layer 3 (active lease) = ongoing operational dashboard. Each layer is a complete, self-contained information set; the host never sees a partial picture within a layer.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Layer 1: 1 new concept + 1 data point (potential income). Layer 2: maximum 5 data points (guest name, schedule, cleaning protocol, incremental income, opt-in/opt-out action). Layer 3: operational view limited to this-week and next-week windows; no multi-month calendar on first load. If the host needs to process more than 5 novel data points in a single view, the layer is overloaded.

elements.title: Agent-to-Platform Trust Transfer Architecture
elements.problem: Every trust-building data point in Mahesh's evaluation came from Bryant, not from the platform. Bryant communicated vetting (02:17), payment guarantee (02:17, 11:01), agreement structure (11:47), cleaning protocol (08:44), and host guarantee (12:21). When Bryant says 'I can get the account set up and send that information through there' (05:05), the platform is positioned as a delivery channel, not a trust source. Cold Start Theory documents how Slack's Stewart Butterfield 'personally handled the lion's share of 10,000 tweets per month and 8,000 customer support tickets' during the early stage -- but this does not scale past the tipping point. The IA problem: when Mahesh arrives on the platform for the first time, the information he encounters must carry the same authority, density, and personalization as Bryant's phone conversation. If the platform presents generic onboarding screens with no reference to what was discussed on the call, the trust built by Bryant evaporates at the transition point. The host's mental model is 'Bryant told me X' -- the platform must confirm 'X is here, as discussed.'
elements.solution: Design the first platform screen as a personalized 'handoff document' that mirrors the call's information structure. The handoff contains: (1) Agent's note ('Hi Mahesh, great talking with you. Here is everything we discussed, ready for your review.'), (2) Pre-populated property details from the call (rent: $2,600, deposit: $1,000, availability: April, amenities: in-unit laundry, street parking with alternate-side rules), (3) Guest profile with vetting status ('Ariel -- Vetted: credit check passed, employment verified'), (4) Guarantee summary ('Payment guaranteed on signing. Property protected up to $1M.'), (5) Next step with single action ('Review Ariel's proposal'). The IA principle: the platform's first screen must be a mirror of the call, not a generic welcome. Every data point Bryant mentioned should appear in the same order and with the same emphasis, so the host recognizes the platform as a continuation of the conversation, not a new starting point.

evidence.quote: If I can grab your email, I can basically get the account set up and then a lot of that information can just be sent to you right through there.
evidence.insight: Bryant promises that 'that information' will be on the platform. The host expects a specific, personalized information set, not a generic dashboard. If the platform delivers less than what was promised on the call, trust degrades.

evidence.quote: Has been vetted and went through our vetting process, including like a credit check. So that's been taken care of as well.
evidence.insight: Bryant compresses vetting into a two-sentence trust statement. The platform must replicate this compression: a 'Vetted' badge is insufficient without the supporting detail ('credit check passed'). The IA must show both the summary and the proof.

evidence.quote: Stewart personally handled the lion's share of 10,000 tweets per month and 8,000 customer support tickets.
evidence.insight: Butterfield's personal handling was essential at cold start but could not scale. The IA must encode the agent's trust-building information into persistent, reusable platform artifacts so that trust scales independently of agent capacity.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary on the host's first platform visit. The handoff document is not a secondary feature -- it IS the onboarding screen. Rationale: the host's trust is currently stored in the agent's voice. The platform must receive that trust transfer before asking for any further commitment.
elements.disclosure_pattern: One-time personalized handoff on first login, then persistent reference. The handoff screen appears once, summarizing the call. After the host advances past it, the data becomes part of the host's dashboard (property details in listing, guest profile in proposals, guarantees in protection status bar). The handoff information is not lost -- it migrates into the standard platform IA.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The handoff screen contains a maximum of 5 sections: (1) agent note, (2) property summary, (3) guest profile, (4) guarantee summary, (5) next action. Each section is a single glanceable block. The total handoff should be readable in under 60 seconds. If the host must scroll more than 2 screen-heights, the handoff is overloaded.

elements.title: Cumulative Evidence Dashboard for Stability Threshold
elements.problem: Ariel's 3-month initial commitment is conditional: 'start with three months and then ideally extend if it was something that worked for her' (03:26). Cold Start Theory identifies that every network has a stability threshold (Slack: 2,000 messages; Uber: ETAs under 3 minutes; Airbnb: 300 listings with 100 reviewed). Split Lease's threshold is the 3-month initial lease -- approximately 12-13 weekly stays. During this period, the host is accumulating evidence for the renewal decision. But the current IA has no mechanism to surface cumulative evidence. Payment information exists but is transactional (each payment shown individually). Property protection status exists but is binary (active/inactive). The host must mentally aggregate 12 weeks of individual data points into a judgment. This is a failure of information architecture: the platform possesses the cumulative data but presents it as discrete events, forcing the host to do the synthesis. The renewal decision should be supported by a pre-synthesized evidence summary, not by a collection of raw transaction records.
elements.solution: Build a 'Lease Health' dashboard that aggregates weekly engagement signals into a cumulative view designed to support the 3-month renewal decision. Structure: (1) Financial summary: total income received to date, percentage of payments on time, projected income through lease end. (2) Property status: number of check-ins completed without incident, property protection claims (ideally zero, which is itself evidence of stability). (3) Guest behavior: check-in/check-out compliance rate, communication responsiveness. (4) Milestone markers at weeks 4, 8, and 12 that summarize the period ('4 weeks complete: $10,400 received, 0 incidents, all check-ins on time'). The dashboard is the host's answer to the question 'Is this working?' At the 3-month mark, it becomes the 'Lease Performance Summary' that presents the renewal decision with concrete evidence, not an open-ended question.

evidence.quote: Start with three months and then ideally extend if it was something that worked for her.
evidence.insight: The phrase 'if it was something that worked' is an evaluation frame. The host will make the renewal decision based on accumulated evidence. The IA must pre-aggregate that evidence rather than leaving the host to mentally compile 12 weeks of individual data points.

evidence.quote: I've never heard of this company... I guess you're doing experience similar to Furnished Finder.
evidence.insight: Mahesh's zero prior relationship means the 3-month lease is his entire evidence base. Every week either builds or erodes his confidence. The IA must make positive accumulation visible so the host does not default to the competitor he already knows.

evidence.quote: After 2,000 messages, 93% of those customers are still using Slack today.
evidence.insight: Slack identified a measurable threshold beyond which retention became near-certain. The cumulative evidence dashboard is Split Lease's mechanism for moving the host toward the equivalent threshold -- making progress visible so the host can see they are approaching stability.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary during active lease. The cumulative evidence dashboard is not a reporting feature -- it is the active lease's primary navigation destination. Rationale: during the 3-month stability test, the host's dominant question is 'Is this working?' The dashboard answers this question; everything else (date changes, messages, settings) is secondary.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Always-on with periodic milestone highlights. The dashboard is accessible at any time and updates after each weekly stay cycle. At weeks 4, 8, and 12, the platform sends a proactive summary notification ('Month 1 complete: $10,400 received, 0 incidents') that links to the full dashboard. The milestone is delivered; the host does not need to seek it out.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The dashboard top-level shows exactly 3 aggregate metrics: (1) total income received, (2) on-time payment rate, (3) incident count. Drill-down to weekly detail is available but not default. The milestone notification contains no more than 3 data points. If the host needs more than 10 seconds to answer 'Is this working?' from the dashboard top-level, the aggregation is insufficient.

elements.title: Decision-Tree-Aligned Vetting Disclosure
elements.problem: Mahesh asks about Ariel's profession (04:00: 'What is Ariel doing? Is she in the... Because she's not in the medical field?') and about vetting details (04:30: 'it's great that you guys do all the credit checked and back on all that stuff'). These two questions reveal two distinct information needs operating on different timescales. The profession question is immediate and personal -- Mahesh is building a mental model of who will be in his property. The vetting question is structural -- he needs to confirm that the platform's process is legitimate. Currently, vetting information is likely presented as a single package: 'Guest is vetted.' But Mahesh's questions show that vetting is not one concept; it is a hierarchy of data points that the host processes in a specific sequence determined by his decision tree. First: who is this person? (identity, profession). Second: are they financially reliable? (credit check). Third: is the platform's process trustworthy? (what does vetting include?). Fourth: will my management company accept this? (exportable documentation). If the IA presents vetting as a flat list or a single badge, it misaligns with the host's processing sequence.
elements.solution: Structure vetting information as a layered profile that follows the host's decision tree. Level 1 (Identity): Guest name, profession, city of origin, reason for stay. This answers 'Who is this person?' and should be the first thing visible on the proposal card. Level 2 (Financial Reliability): Credit check result (pass/fail with general score range), employment verification status, income-to-rent ratio if available. This answers 'Can they pay?' Level 3 (Platform Process): What the vetting process included (credit check, identity verification, references), when it was completed, and the agent's endorsement note. This answers 'Is this platform legitimate?' Level 4 (Exportable): The management-company-formatted application (see communicates-002). Each level is expandable from the previous, following the host's natural question sequence. The host never needs to ask 'what was checked?' because the answer is embedded in the hierarchy.

evidence.quote: What is Ariel doing? Is she in the... Because she's not in the medical field?
evidence.insight: Mahesh's first question about the guest is professional identity, not financial status. The host's decision tree starts with 'who' before 'how much.' The IA must respect this sequence.

evidence.quote: It's great that you guys do all the credit checked and back on all that stuff. I probably need that information to share with my management.
evidence.insight: Mahesh conflates two needs in one sentence: personal confidence in vetting ('it's great') and institutional export ('I need that information'). The IA must serve both without making the host re-request the same data in a different format.

evidence.quote: Acquiring the hard side of the network and keeping them happy is paramount to standing up an atomic network.
evidence.insight: The hard side evaluates thoroughly. A single 'Vetted' badge without layered detail will not satisfy a thorough evaluator like Mahesh. The IA must provide depth on demand, structured in the sequence the hard side naturally processes.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary on the proposal card (guest identity and vetting are the core content of a proposal). Within the vetting section, the hierarchy follows the host's decision tree: identity > financial reliability > platform process > exportable documentation. Each level is a complete answer to one question; the host can stop at any level if satisfied.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Progressive expansion along the decision tree. Level 1 (identity) is always visible on the proposal card. Level 2 (financial reliability) is one tap to expand. Level 3 (platform process) is a further expansion within Level 2. Level 4 (export) is an action button, not a display. Each level adds detail without repeating the previous level's content.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Level 1: 4 data points (name, profession, city, reason for stay). Level 2: 3 data points (credit result, employment status, income ratio). Level 3: 3 data points (checks performed, completion date, agent note). No level exceeds 4 data points. The host should be able to reach full confidence within 3 expansions or fewer.

elements.title: Agreement Counterparty Clarity Architecture
elements.problem: Mahesh asks 'the agreement is, is it between which we, you know, for me, at least on my side, is it with you guys or it's a, the record?' (11:27). Bryant answers that Split Lease 'creates and hosts the agreement' and it is 'between yourself and then the one or two guests' (11:47). This exchange reveals a fundamental information architecture gap: the host does not know who his counterparty is. In a traditional rental, the counterparty is obvious -- the tenant. In Split Lease's model, the counterparty could be: the guest, Split Lease itself, or both (and possibly a ghost roommate as a third party). When Mahesh asks about property damage (12:04), he again needs to know the counterparty: 'Is that something that I would work with you or would that with the...' The IA must make the counterparty structure unambiguous at every phase, because the host's willingness to proceed depends on knowing who is on the other side of every obligation. Cold Start Theory shows that atomic networks require clear participant roles -- 'the right people, at the same time, using the product in the right way.'
elements.solution: Surface a persistent 'Who's Involved' structure on every agreement-related screen that clearly identifies each party's role and responsibility. The structure: (1) 'Your Agreement' header with the parties named: 'Between you (Mahesh) and Ariel [Guest], hosted by Split Lease.' (2) Responsibility map: 'Payments: Split Lease guarantees and collects. Property protection: Split Lease covers up to $1M. Deposit: Split Lease holds $1,000. Communication: Direct with guest via platform. Disputes: Contact Split Lease.' (3) On the active lease dashboard, the counterparty structure appears in a 'Your Arrangement' summary card that the host can reference at any time without navigating away. The IA principle: the host should never wonder 'who do I call?' The counterparty for each type of interaction (payment, protection, communication, disputes) is explicitly labeled.

evidence.quote: The agreement is, is it between which we, you know, for me, at least on my side, is it with you guys or it's a, the record?
evidence.insight: Mahesh cannot parse the contractual structure from the conversation alone. The agreement has three parties (host, guest, platform) with different roles. The IA must make this multi-party structure visually explicit, not textually buried in agreement terms.

evidence.quote: How does the deposit get sorted out? Is that something that I would work with you or would that with the...
evidence.insight: For each type of interaction (deposit, damage, payment), Mahesh needs to know the specific counterparty. A generic 'Split Lease handles everything' is insufficient -- the host needs to know which entity to contact for which concern.

evidence.quote: Solving the Cold Start Problem requires getting all the right users and content on the same network at the same time.
evidence.insight: The atomic network has clear roles: host provides property, guest provides occupancy, platform provides guarantees and infrastructure. If the host cannot identify these roles, the network feels amorphous and untrustworthy.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Secondary on most screens (the host references it when a question arises, not on every visit). But on the agreement signing screen and the dispute/claim initiation screen, it becomes primary -- the host must know exactly who is on the other side before signing or filing a claim.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Persistent reference card. A 'Your Arrangement' card appears in the sidebar or header of the lease dashboard. It is always one tap away but does not dominate the screen. On agreement-signing and claim-initiation screens, the counterparty structure is promoted to primary position. The pattern: always accessible, contextually elevated when the host is making a binding decision.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The counterparty structure has exactly 4 responsibility categories: payments, property protection, communication, and disputes. Each category maps to one counterparty (Split Lease or guest). No more than 4 categories; no ambiguous 'it depends' answers. If the host must read more than 4 lines to understand who handles what, the structure is overloaded.
